#### Section 1: Solar cells
Interactions between light and matter determine much about the way that
sighted individuals observe the world. Indeed, absorption and scattering
largely determine which photons reach our eyes in the natural
environment. In technology, the engineering of light-matter interactions
is critical in two areas of application: solar photovoltaic cells and
devices for lighting and display. This chapter reviews some of the basic
principles of these devices. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/zZg5MXKCwCI)

The photophysical processes we have discussed so far are central to the
operation of solar cells and light-emitting devices. The first step in
the operation of a solar cell occurs when a semiconductor material in
the **photoactive layer** absorbs a photon. This material can absorb
photons with energy equal to or in excess of its band gap, where the
probability of photon absorption depends on the material's absorptivity
and density of states. The absorption of a photon will cause the
excitation of an electron, followed by rapid thermalization of the
electron to the band edge. This process produces an electron, $e^-$, in
the conduction band and leaves a hole, h$^+$, in the valence band. From
there, the details differ depending on the type of solar cell being
discussed.

### 9.1.1. Silicon solar cells

Conventional solar cells based on polycrystalline or monocrystalline
silicon are what---at the time of this writing---are probably on the
roof of a nearby building, or the building you are in. This technology
currently exhibits the best compromise between efficiency, lifetime,
stability, and cost.

#### p-n Junctions

The basic architecture of a silicon solar cell is a **p-n junction**
(see Figure (9.1)), in which a slab of p-type silicon makes intimate
contact with a slab of n-type silicon. Normal silicon is tetravalent,
meaning that it makes four bonds to nearby atoms. The structure of
crystalline silicon has a tetrahedral arrangement, which is the same
structure as diamond.[^9.1.1] Due to this state in which all covalent bonds
exactly satisfy the preferred bonding arrangement for silicon, the
electrons are not very mobile. Thus, pure silicon is not very conductive
at all, exhibiting borderline insulating behavior at room temperature.

(Figure 9.1) 
>>>image(p-n junction.png.0)

#### Doping

When atoms are added to the structure of pure silicon in a process
called **doping**, the conductivity is altered. For example, "p-type"
silicon is so-called because it is doped with an element with a valency
of less than four. The most common p-type dopant is boron, which has
three valence electrons. When boron is added to silicon (in minute
quantities \<\<1%), there is a **hole** in the crystal structure due to
a "missing" electron since boron can only form a full covalent bond with
up to three of its neighbors. This hole can backfill with a nearby
electron, which thus creates a hole in the bond between two silicon
atoms. The backfilling of these holes by electrons is the mechanism by
which p-type silicon conducts electricity. For n-type silicon, the most
common elements used as dopants are phosphorus or arsenic, which each
have five valence electrons. In this case, electrical conduction is
achieved by the movement of these "extra" electrons.

It is important to remember that neither p-type nor n-type silicon is
formally charged. Saying that the silicon is p-type does not mean it
carries a positive charge. Remember that while there are "missing"
electrons because there are boron atoms in the crystal lattice, boron
also has one fewer proton than silicon. This point is easy to forget.

#### Formation of the depletion zone

When p-type and n-type silicon are pressed together to form a p-n
junction, something weird happens. Some of the extra electrons from the
n-type side migrate over to the p-type side in order to satisfy the
unfilled valencies. The result of this migration is that *the p-type
side becomes negatively charged and the n-type side becomes positively
charged!* The charged zones near the interface do not penetrate all the
way into either side of the junction. The width---**the depletion
zone**---depends on doping level of the silicon and ultimately on the
increase in electrostatic potential energy due to confining charges
nearby one another. Nevertheless, the positive and negative charges on
either side of the depletion zone form an electric field. This built-in
field is capable of sorting negative and positive charges to opposite
sides of the junction. The following figure, (9.2), depicts how a p-n
junction creates an electric field.

(Figure 9.2) 
>>>image(energy level diagram.png.0)

#### Absorption

Silicon is what is called an **indirect band gap semiconductor**, which
means that the valence band edge and the conduction band edge are not
aligned, and thus despite its small band gap of only 1.1 eV, silicon
must be a few tens of microns thick in order to absorb all incident
photons with energy in excess of the band gap.[^9.1.2] In the cases where a
photon is successfully absorbed by the silicon in a p-n junction, the
electron in the conduction band and the hole left behind in the valence
band dissociate from each other immediately. Once separated, these
photogenerated electrons and holes actually have negative and positive
charges associated with them. The fact that the opposite charges do not
immediately recombine is due to the relatively high dielectric constant
of silicon, which lowers the electrostatic potential energy of the
individual charges.

#### The photovoltaic effect

Eventually, the charges feel the pull of the built-in electric field of
the depletion zone and are shuttled to opposite ends of the device. The
difference in potential energy per charge---i.e., the voltage of the
device---depends on the difference in energy between the conduction band
of the p-type side and the valence band of the n-type side (since those
are the bands where the charges live). When there is no load connected
to the device (or a load of infinite resistance), this voltage is called
the **open-circuit voltage, *V*$_{oc}$** When the two sides of the
device are connected with a thick metal wire (effectively zero
resistance), the charges move into the circuit to recombine with each
other. The resulting maximum possible current is called the
**short-circuit current, *I*$_{sc}$**. When a load is placed in between
the two terminals, the maximum power achievable is ideally equal to
*V*$_{oc}$ $\times$ *I*$_{sc}$ but never is. Instead, various parasitic
processes in the device reduce the maximum power to something like
60-95% of the ideal value. The ratio of this value to the ideal value is
called the **fill factor**. The ratio of the maximum power to the input
solar power is the **power conversion efficiency**. The diagram shown in
Figure (9.3) depicts how these values relate to one another.

(Figure 9.3) 
>>>image(jv curve.png.0)

### 9.1.2. Excitonic solar cells

There is another type of solar cell based on organic semiconductors and
semiconductor nanocrystals (i.e., quantum dots). This type of solar
cell---termed an **excitonic solar cell**---differs from conventional
silicon solar cells in several ways, enumerated as follows.

1.  The dielectric constant of the medium is lower than silicon.

2.  The low dielectric constant means that that photogenerated charges
    are not separated immediately. Instead, an electrostatically bound
    and neutral electron-hole pair---**an exciton**---is generated.

3.  This exciton must reach an interface between a material which is an
    electron donor and one which is an electron acceptor.

4.  The donor serves the same function as the p-type silicon in a
    conventional cell, but the donor is not doped and thus has no mobile
    charge carriers.

5.  Since there is no doping, putting a donor and an acceptor in
    intimate contact does not produce a depletion zone.

6.  Most organic semiconductors and quantum dots are **direct band gap
    semiconductors**, which means that they can be up to 1000$\times$
    thinner than silicon cells.

7.  Excitonic materials can often be deposited from solution over large
    areas and at low cost.

8.  Unfortunately, excitonic solar cells have lower efficiencies and
    device lifetimes compared to conventional silicon cells.

#### Generation of photovoltage in excitonic cells

Given all of the ways in which these excitonic---"alternative"---types
of semiconductors differ from conventional silicon, it is surprising
that they exhibit a photovoltaic effect at all. With no depletion layer,
one may question how the charges reach the opposite sides of the device.
In the case of excitonic cells, it is essential that the metallic
electrodes used to extract the charges have different values of **work
function**. The work function of the anode should be close to the
valence band edge of the donor (where the holes come out, very roughly
around 5 eV), and the work function of the cathode must be close to the
conduction band edge of the acceptor (where the electrons come out, very
roughly around 3 eV). When the electrodes are connected, there is a
shuttling of electrons from the cathode to the anode, and thus the
cathode takes on a small positive charge and the anode takes on a small
negative charge. Thus, an electric field is created in the device. Once
the exciton splits into free charge carriers---i.e., where the electron
goes to the acceptor and the hole goes into the donor---the electric
field in the device causes the electrons to drift toward the cathode and
the holes to drift toward the anode. This process is the basis of the
photovoltaic effect in excitonic solar cells.

One major complication of the excitonic solar cell is that the distance
an exciton can travel---**exciton diffusion length**---is typically 5-10
times shorter than the thickness of the film needed to absorb most of
the light, which for our purposes can be taken as the **absorption
length**. Thus, typical exciton diffusion lengths are on the order of 10
nm, while typical absorption lengths can be on the order of 100 nm. A
consequence of this disparity is that devices with a flat, planar
interface between the donor and the acceptor are inherently inefficient.
The reason is that for devices with thicknesses of 100 nm, most of the
excitons generated will not reach the interface, and will just collapse:
the energy will either be radiated as a fluorescent photon or it will be
lost as heat. For devices of 10 nm or so in thickness, most of the
excitons will find the interface and separate, but most of the light
will pass through the device, unabsorbed.

The most common way around this challenge is to cast both the donor and
the acceptor material from the same solution. Under favorable
conditions, the two materials separate into a donor phase and an
acceptor phase whose dimensions are close to the exciton diffusion
length, but whose overall thickness is close to the absorption length.
The resulting blended architecture is called the **bulk
heterojunction**, see Figure (9.4). This architecture simplifies
processing but has some disadvantages, as enumerated below.

(Figure 9.4) 
>>>image(BHJ.png.0)

1.  The donor and the acceptor phases make contact with both electrodes

2.  Some donor and acceptor phases get "stranded" like an island in a
    sea of the other material

3.  The chemical potential gradient established for a planar device
    which ordinarily pushes charges in the correct direction now faces
    in random directions

Methods to achieve the best of both worlds of the planar and bulk
heterojunction involve the fabrication of an **ordered bulk
heterojunction** in which top-down nanolithography or bottom-up self
assembly processes are used to create precisely interpenetrating
networks with bicontinuity of the two phases. Notwithstanding, these
efforts have so far not been successful, and the bulk heterojunction
type excitonic solar cell (typically polymer based) is the most
efficient type of excitonic solar cell. Moreover, it is becoming
increasingly apparent that some level of molecular mixing at the
interfaces (shown as the purple "halos" around the red and blue phases
in Figure (9.4)) is actually better for charge separation than a
geometry in which the layers are perfectly separated.

### 9.1.3. Perovskite solar cells

A final type of solar cell which has some characteristics of the
excitonic solar cell, especially its ultrathin stature, is the
**perovskite solar cell**. A perovksite cell is so named because the
crystal structure of the semiconductor absorber is the same as the
mineral with the name of perovskite, CaTiO$_3$. The general formula is
ABX$_3$, where A is usually a polar organic molecule (methylammonium,
CH$_3$NH$_3$), B is a metal, and X is a halide. The composition of
perovskite materials that is among the most promising---or at least
where most of the research is headed---is methylammonium lead iodide,
CH$_3$NH$_3$PbI$_3$, see Figure (9.5).

(Figure 9.5) 
>>>image(perovskite.png.0)

The way in which a perovskite device works has elements of both a
conventional (i.e., silicon) and excitonic (i.e., organic) solar cell.
First off, the perovskite material is a direct bandgap semiconductor,
meaning that the device can be very thin.[^9.1.3] The perovskite structure
also has a high dielectric constant, and shields charges effectively.
Thus, as soon as a photon is absorbed, free charges are immediately
generated. These charges drift around the active layer. What is required
is charge-selective contacts that shuttle either electrons, **the
electron transport layer (ETL)**, or holes, **the hole transport layer
(HTL)**, out to the electrodes. This selective separation of charges is
the basis of the photovoltaic effect in perovskite solar cells. Often,
the ETL, HTL, or both, are organic, and sometimes are $\pi$-conjugated
polymers. Thus, innovations in the chemistry and physics of organic
semiconductors could be useful in the development of perovskite devices.

### 9.1.4. Tandem solar cells

There are many ways in which combining the attributes of solar cells are
advantageous. For example, connecting cells in parallel can generate
larger currents (equivalent to increasing the size of a single cell).
Conversely, connecting cells in series can generate larger voltages.
Connection in series enables one to create **tandem devices**, in which
different cells with different absorption characteristics are
constructed on top of one another, like a stack of pancakes (Figure
(9.6)). This approach allows one to tailor the absorption properties of
a collection of cells to cover as much of the solar spectrum as
possible. For example, a large-bandgap semiconductor (absorbs
higher-energy, bluer light) might sit atop a low-bandgap semiconductor
(absorbs lower-energy, redder light). To reiterate, when one connects
cells in parallel, one adds up the currents of the individual cells, and
when one connects cells in series, one adds up the voltages.

(Figure 9.6) 
>>>image(tandem.png.0)

[^9.1.1]: Silicon and carbon are both members of group 4 of the period
    table, and thus have four valence electrons.

[^9.1.2]: For context, other semiconductor materials used in solar cells,
    such as perovskites, can capture comparable amounts of light with
    sub-micron film thicknesses

[^9.1.3]: The bandgap can also be adjusted by tuning the elemental
    composition of the absorber layer.

#### Section 2: Light-emitting devices and display technologies
While solar cells convert light to electricity, light-emitting devices
and displays convert electricity to light. Display technologies have
always been intimately connected to methods of generating light for
interior and exterior use. For example, incandescent light bulbs lit
rooms and streets as well as provided the back light for movie
projectors. Nowadays, the technology that underlies most indoor,
outdoor, and automotive lighting is the **light-emitting diode (LED)**.
An LED is essentially a solar cell in reverse. That is, charges are
injected into the semiconductor, and when they recombine, they emit a
photon, in a process known as **electroluminescence**. This process is
ubiquitous in current display technologies, but there are important
differences between them. These differences can be obscured by the often
confusing language with which they are referred. For example, devices
labeled "LED" and "OLED" operate using principles which differ
considerably from each other.

### 9.2.1. Brief history of display technologies

We are approaching the generation of college students who never used a
**cathode ray tube (CRT)** television or computer monitor. A
**monochrome** (single-color) CRT display uses a vacuum tube with an
electron gun in the back of the display. Electrons are emitted by a
process called **thermionic emission** in which a metal filament is
heated up at the cathode and accelerated toward the screen by a high
voltage. An electromagnetic field scans this **cathode ray** across the
screen in a pattern defined by the input. As the ray scans across
**phosphors**[^9.2.1] embedded in the glass screen, an image is created. A
color display[^9.2.2] has three different types of phosphors, which emit
red, green, and blue when impinged upon by a beam of electrons (the
cathode ray).

For most of the history of CRT displays, they were configured as
**analog**. That is, they produced images in response to a continuously
variable signal. With analog technology, errors are propagated easily
and highly susceptible to interference. Those of us who have ever
fiddled with rabbit-ear antennae to improve the quality of the picture
on a TV can attest. The maximum resolution of a CRT display is defined
by the **dot pitch**, or the spacing between triads of RGB
color-emitting phosphors.

In contrast to an analog display, which is subject to the accumulation
of error, a digital display permits much more accurate and error-free
rendering of images. Most modern displays---your TV, laptop, and
smartphone---are digital. The advent of digital displays corresponded to
a progression of flat-screen technologies that has largely supplanted
CRT displays. The first widely adopted flat-panel displays were based on
**plasma** and **liquid crystal** technologies.

### 9.2.2. Digital display technologies

Plasma displays are glass panels with little closed pockets of inert gas
sandwiched by transparent conductive electrodes. A **radio frequency
(RF)** electrical signal ionizes the gas in the pockets to form a
**plasma**. These charged species excite phosphors embedded in the
interior surface of the glass, which emit light. There are three
**subpixels**---red, green, and blue---per pixel in a color display. The
number of pixels is equal to the resolution, for example, 1920 $\times$
1080.[^9.2.3]

#### Liquid crystal displays

A **liquid crystal display (LCD)** is a type of flat-panel technology
that uses a layer of liquid crystals to control how much light is
passing between a white backlight and a large array of RGB color
filters. Figure (9.7) shows the concept. First of all, a liquid crystal
is a type of material, described in Chapter 6, in which the liquid
phase, at certain temperature, has the unusual property of molecular
alignment. These aligned molecules can interact with unpolarized light,
and thus only polarized light may pass through. The concept is exploited
in polarized sunglasses. If you put these glasses under a microscope,
you will find a series of microscopic dark lines arrayed like Venetian
blinds. These lines block out half of the light, and what light passes
through becomes polarized along the axis of the lines. In fact, if you
take your polarized sunglasses and rotate them (or tip your head 90
$^{\circ}$ ) while looking at an LCD, it will go dark. The near-total
loss of light intensity reaching your eyes occurs because the polarized
light that emerges from the display is blocked by the polarizer in your
sunglasses, if your sunglasses are oriented at 90 $^{\circ}$ . Two
sunglasses lenses placed at 90 $^{\circ}$ to each other will have the
same effect. However, if you put multiple polarizers in a stack, and
rotate each one from 0 to 90 $^{\circ}$ , you will actually let the
light through. With this trick, you are effectively rotating the light
gradually, through each polarizer, like a spiral. Thus, each polarizer
rotates the light a little bit, so that it reaches the final polarizer
which is oriented such as to let the light through. This is the
principle by which an LCD works.

(Figure 9.7) 
>>>image(LCD.png.0)

The steps are as follows. First, light is generated by a **backlight**,
typically by an array of conventional silicon LEDs.[^9.2.4] The light then
passes through an electrode connected to a polarizer. The kind of
polarizer used in LCDs contains parallel microscopic grooves. The next
layer is the liquid crystal layer. Rigid, rod-like molecules like those
that form liquid crystals sit in these grooves with their axes oriented
in the same direction as the grooves. Following the liquid crystal layer
is another polarizer oriented 90 $^{\circ}$ to the first. Where the
liquid crystal layer comes into contact with this second polarizer, it
must perform a quarter twist in the space between the two polarizers in
a process called **self-assembly**. The next layer is another electrode,
followed by a color filter. That is, a little piece of dyed plastic or
glass, which lets through red, green, or blue light through. When light
of different intensities are passed through adjacent red, green, and
blue subpixels, nearly any color can be generated---that is, when
observed by somebody some distance away.[^9.2.5]

The intensity of the light coming through each subpixel is controlled by
the electrical potential difference (i.e., the voltage) between the
electrodes on either side of the liquid crystal layer. When no voltage
is applied, the light from the backlight is rotated 90 $^{\circ}$ from
the rear polarizer to the front polarizer. So, while half the light is
blocked by the first polarizer---nothing you can do about that---the
rest of the light passes through to the color filter. However, when
voltage is applied, you can get the quarter turn of the liquid crystal
to straighten out and become parallel to either the front or back
polarizer. When the voltage is at maximum, all of the light is
blocked.[^9.2.6] The voltage at each subpixel is controlled by arrays of
transparent **thin-film transistors** at every location in an
**active-matrix** display. Advantages of LCD technology are that they
use relatively low energy (compared to plasma displays) and are
relatively inexpensive to manufacture. The significant downside of LCDs
is that since the backlight is always on, and there is always some
leakage through the LC layer, it is difficult to achieve very high
levels of contrast between light and dark pixels.

#### Organic light-emitting displays (OLEDs)

The issue of relatively low contrast in LCDs can be addressed by using a
separate backlight for each subpixel. That way, pixels can truly be off,
permitting an effective "infinite" contrast ratio between adjacent
pixels in the display. The only technology for backlighting currently
capable of the required resolution is the **organic light-emitting
device (OLED)**. The resolution is achieved by evaporation of organic
semiconductor molecules through a stencil mask with very small holes.
These molecules when electrically stimulated emit white light. The white
light then travels through the RGB color filters at an intensity
determined by the voltage applied to the OLED backlights. Note that no
liquid crystal layer is required in this case, though most commercial
OLED displays still use the color filters. Figure (9.8) illustrates the
operation of a pixel in such a display. You might ask why the organic
semiconductors are not designed simply to emit red, green, and blue,
without the need of the semiconductors. It turns out that while red and
green are amenable to this approach, blue is not. The reason is that
organic semiconductors that emit blue degrade faster than those emitting
red and green. This unequal rate of degradation produces an uneven color
gamut over time.

(Figure 9.8) 
>>>image(OLED.png.0)

#### Displays using quantum dots.

Quantum dots are fluorescent nanoparticles that have many of the same
properties as organic semiconductors. However, when you see a "QLED"
display at the store, the display does not work by the same principle as
an OLED. Instead, a QLED display is basically the same thing as an LCD,
except that a diffuser panel covered in quantum dots is inserted in
front of the LED backlight. The quantum dot layer absorbs the high
energy photons of the white light---which apparently are not pleasing to
the eye---and re-emits them as fluorescent photons with lower energy. A
newer generation of displays enabled by quantum dots is under active
investigation. This technology works analogously to OLEDs, except that
quantum dots are less susceptible to degradation, meaning that it may be
possible to have direct RGB emission and thus eliminate the need for the
color filters all together.

Solar cells and lighting (display) technologies represent real, tangible
applications of photophysical processes in nanoscale materials. They are
also of interest to researchers concerned with generation and efficient
use of energy. For solar cells, researchers are constantly trying to
optimize devices to produce more energy at lower costs by reducing
thermalization losses, developing tandem devices, and researching
nanoscale processes for light management (i.e., using plasmonic antenna
structures or topographic light-trapping features). While displays do
not account for a huge amount of global energy expenditure, displays are
intimately linked to lighting technologies. Domestic, commercial, and
outdoor lighting in fact do consume a significant amount of energy, and
I hope that this chapter allowed you to consider some of the ways in
which nanoengineering can be used to improve them.

    element phosphorous nor the process of phosphorescence.

[^9.2.2]: Actually capable of three colors---red, green, and blue---to match
    with the light-sensitive cone cells in the eyes.

[^9.2.3]: The maximum resolution of such a display is 1080p, where the "p"
    stands for *progressive*. In a progressive display, p, the
    horizontal rows of the display are refreshed all at once. In
    contrast, in an *interlaced* signal---e.g., 1080i---the rows of the
    display are refreshed alternately. Thus, the video signal can be
    transmitted with half the data at a resolution that looks similar to
    the eyes of most untrained viewers.

[^9.2.4]: The backlight used to be derived from a fluorescent light bulb,
    but LEDs are better in terms of energy efficiency and contrast.

[^9.2.5]: Ever notice when a drop of water lands on your laptop or phone
    screen and just like as if peering through a magnifying glass you
    can see the red green and blue subpixels?

### 9.1.2. Excitonic solar cells

semiconductor nanocrystals (i.e., quantum dots). This type of solar
cell---termed an **excitonic solar cell**---differs from conventional

    electron donor and one which is an electron acceptor.

4.  The donor serves the same function as the p-type silicon in a
    conventional cell, but the donor is not doped and thus has no mobile
    charge carriers.

one may question how the charges reach the opposite sides of the device.
In the case of excitonic cells, it is essential that the metallic
electrodes used to extract the charges have different values of **work
function**. The work function of the anode should be close to the

field in the device causes the electrons to drift toward the cathode and
the holes to drift toward the anode. This process is the basis of the
photovoltaic effect in excitonic solar cells.

nm, while typical absorption lengths can be on the order of 100 nm. A

interface between the donor and the acceptor are inherently inefficient.

excitons will find the interface and separate, but most of the light

environment. In technology, the engineering of light-matter interactions

#### Doping

When atoms are added to the structure of pure silicon in a process

up to three of its neighbors. This hole can backfill with a nearby
electron, which thus creates a hole in the bond between two silicon
atoms. The backfilling of these holes by electrons is the mechanism by

common elements used as dopants are phosphorus or arsenic, which each

achieved by the movement of these "extra" electrons.

formally charged. Saying that the silicon is p-type does not mean it

also has one fewer proton than silicon. This point is easy to forget.

#### Section 2: Light-emitting devices and display technologies
While solar cells convert light to electricity, light-emitting devices
and displays convert electricity to light. Display technologies have
always been intimately connected to methods of generating light for
interior and exterior use. For example, incandescent light bulbs lit
rooms and streets as well as provided the back light for movie
projectors. Nowadays, the technology that underlies most indoor,
outdoor, and automotive lighting is the **light-emitting diode (LED)**.
An LED is essentially a solar cell in reverse. That is, charges are
injected into the semiconductor, and when they recombine, they emit a
photon, in a process known as **electroluminescence**. This process is
ubiquitous in current display technologies, but there are important
differences between them. These differences can be obscured by the often
confusing language with which they are referred. For example, devices
labeled "LED" and "OLED" operate using principles which differ
considerably from each other.

### 9.2.1. Brief history of display technologies

We are approaching the generation of college students who never used a
**cathode ray tube (CRT)** television or computer monitor. A
**monochrome** (single-color) CRT display uses a vacuum tube with an
electron gun in the back of the display. Electrons are emitted by a
process called **thermionic emission** in which a metal filament is
heated up at the cathode and accelerated toward the screen by a high
voltage. An electromagnetic field scans this **cathode ray** across the
screen in a pattern defined by the input. As the ray scans across
**phosphors**[^9.2.1] embedded in the glass screen, an image is created. A
color display[^9.2.2] has three different types of phosphors, which emit
red, green, and blue when impinged upon by a beam of electrons (the
cathode ray).

For most of the history of CRT displays, they were configured as
**analog**. That is, they produced images in response to a continuously
variable signal. With analog technology, errors are propagated easily
and highly susceptible to interference. Those of us who have ever
fiddled with rabbit-ear antennae to improve the quality of the picture
on a TV can attest. The maximum resolution of a CRT display is defined
by the **dot pitch**, or the spacing between triads of RGB
color-emitting phosphors.

In contrast to an analog display, which is subject to the accumulation
of error, a digital display permits much more accurate and error-free
rendering of images. Most modern displays---your TV, laptop, and
smartphone---are digital. The advent of digital displays corresponded to
a progression of flat-screen technologies that has largely supplanted
CRT displays. The first widely adopted flat-panel displays were based on
**plasma** and **liquid crystal** technologies.

### 9.2.2. Digital display technologies

Plasma displays are glass panels with little closed pockets of inert gas
sandwiched by transparent conductive electrodes. A **radio frequency
(RF)** electrical signal ionizes the gas in the pockets to form a
**plasma**. These charged species excite phosphors embedded in the
interior surface of the glass, which emit light. There are three
**subpixels**---red, green, and blue---per pixel in a color display. The
number of pixels is equal to the resolution, for example, 1920 $\times$
1080.[^9.2.3]

#### Liquid crystal displays

A **liquid crystal display (LCD)** is a type of flat-panel technology
that uses a layer of liquid crystals to control how much light is
passing between a white backlight and a large array of RGB color
filters. Figure (9.7) shows the concept. First of all, a liquid crystal
is a type of material, described in Chapter 6, in which the liquid
phase, at certain temperature, has the unusual property of molecular
alignment. These aligned molecules can interact with unpolarized light,
and thus only polarized light may pass through. The concept is exploited
in polarized sunglasses. If you put these glasses under a microscope,
you will find a series of microscopic dark lines arrayed like Venetian
blinds. These lines block out half of the light, and what light passes
through becomes polarized along the axis of the lines. In fact, if you
take your polarized sunglasses and rotate them (or tip your head 90
$^{\circ}$ ) while looking at an LCD, it will go dark. The near-total
loss of light intensity reaching your eyes occurs because the polarized
light that emerges from the display is blocked by the polarizer in your
sunglasses, if your sunglasses are oriented at 90 $^{\circ}$ . Two
sunglasses lenses placed at 90 $^{\circ}$ to each other will have the
same effect. However, if you put multiple polarizers in a stack, and
rotate each one from 0 to 90 $^{\circ}$ , you will actually let the
light through. With this trick, you are effectively rotating the light
gradually, through each polarizer, like a spiral. Thus, each polarizer
rotates the light a little bit, so that it reaches the final polarizer
which is oriented such as to let the light through. This is the
principle by which an LCD works.

(Figure 9.7) 
>>>image(LCD.png.0)

The steps are as follows. First, light is generated by a **backlight**,
typically by an array of conventional silicon LEDs.[^9.2.4] The light then
passes through an electrode connected to a polarizer. The kind of
polarizer used in LCDs contains parallel microscopic grooves. The next
layer is the liquid crystal layer. Rigid, rod-like molecules like those
that form liquid crystals sit in these grooves with their axes oriented
in the same direction as the grooves. Following the liquid crystal layer
is another polarizer oriented 90 $^{\circ}$ to the first. Where the
liquid crystal layer comes into contact with this second polarizer, it
must perform a quarter twist in the space between the two polarizers in
a process called **self-assembly**. The next layer is another electrode,
followed by a color filter. That is, a little piece of dyed plastic or
glass, which lets through red, green, or blue light through. When light
of different intensities are passed through adjacent red, green, and
blue subpixels, nearly any color can be generated---that is, when
observed by somebody some distance away.[^9.2.5]

The intensity of the light coming through each subpixel is controlled by
the electrical potential difference (i.e., the voltage) between the
electrodes on either side of the liquid crystal layer. When no voltage
is applied, the light from the backlight is rotated 90 $^{\circ}$ from
the rear polarizer to the front polarizer. So, while half the light is
blocked by the first polarizer---nothing you can do about that---the
rest of the light passes through to the color filter. However, when
voltage is applied, you can get the quarter turn of the liquid crystal
to straighten out and become parallel to either the front or back
polarizer. When the voltage is at maximum, all of the light is
blocked.[^9.2.6] The voltage at each subpixel is controlled by arrays of
transparent **thin-film transistors** at every location in an
**active-matrix** display. Advantages of LCD technology are that they
use relatively low energy (compared to plasma displays) and are
relatively inexpensive to manufacture. The significant downside of LCDs
is that since the backlight is always on, and there is always some

#### Section 1: Solar cells
Interactions between light and matter determine much about the way that
sighted individuals observe the world. Indeed, absorption and scattering
largely determine which photons reach our eyes in the natural
environment. In technology, the engineering of light-matter interactions
is critical in two areas of application: solar photovoltaic cells and
devices for lighting and display. This chapter reviews some of the basic
principles of these devices. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/zZg5MXKCwCI)

The photophysical processes we have discussed so far are central to the
operation of solar cells and light-emitting devices. The first step in
the operation of a solar cell occurs when a semiconductor material in
the **photoactive layer** absorbs a photon. This material can absorb
photons with energy equal to or in excess of its band gap, where the
probability of photon absorption depends on the material's absorptivity
and density of states. The absorption of a photon will cause the
excitation of an electron, followed by rapid thermalization of the
electron to the band edge. This process produces an electron, $e^-$, in
the conduction band and leaves a hole, h$^+$, in the valence band. From
there, the details differ depending on the type of solar cell being
discussed.

### 9.1.1. Silicon solar cells

Conventional solar cells based on polycrystalline or monocrystalline
silicon are what---at the time of this writing---are probably on the
roof of a nearby building, or the building you are in. This technology
currently exhibits the best compromise between efficiency, lifetime,
stability, and cost.

#### p-n Junctions

The basic architecture of a silicon solar cell is a **p-n junction**
(see Figure (9.1)), in which a slab of p-type silicon makes intimate
contact with a slab of n-type silicon. Normal silicon is tetravalent,
meaning that it makes four bonds to nearby atoms. The structure of
crystalline silicon has a tetrahedral arrangement, which is the same
structure as diamond.[^9.1.1] Due to this state in which all covalent bonds
exactly satisfy the preferred bonding arrangement for silicon, the
electrons are not very mobile. Thus, pure silicon is not very conductive
at all, exhibiting borderline insulating behavior at room temperature.

(Figure 9.1) 
>>>image(p-n junction.png.0)

#### Doping

When atoms are added to the structure of pure silicon in a process
called **doping**, the conductivity is altered. For example, "p-type"
silicon is so-called because it is doped with an element with a valency
of less than four. The most common p-type dopant is boron, which has
three valence electrons. When boron is added to silicon (in minute
quantities \<\<1%), there is a **hole** in the crystal structure due to
a "missing" electron since boron can only form a full covalent bond with
up to three of its neighbors. This hole can backfill with a nearby
electron, which thus creates a hole in the bond between two silicon
atoms. The backfilling of these holes by electrons is the mechanism by
which p-type silicon conducts electricity. For n-type silicon, the most
common elements used as dopants are phosphorus or arsenic, which each
have five valence electrons. In this case, electrical conduction is
achieved by the movement of these "extra" electrons.

It is important to remember that neither p-type nor n-type silicon is
formally charged. Saying that the silicon is p-type does not mean it
carries a positive charge. Remember that while there are "missing"
electrons because there are boron atoms in the crystal lattice, boron
also has one fewer proton than silicon. This point is easy to forget.

#### Formation of the depletion zone

When p-type and n-type silicon are pressed together to form a p-n
junction, something weird happens. Some of the extra electrons from the
n-type side migrate over to the p-type side in order to satisfy the
unfilled valencies. The result of this migration is that *the p-type
side becomes negatively charged and the n-type side becomes positively
charged!* The charged zones near the interface do not penetrate all the
way into either side of the junction. The width---**the depletion
zone**---depends on doping level of the silicon and ultimately on the
increase in electrostatic potential energy due to confining charges
nearby one another. Nevertheless, the positive and negative charges on
either side of the depletion zone form an electric field. This built-in
field is capable of sorting negative and positive charges to opposite
sides of the junction. The following figure, (9.2), depicts how a p-n
junction creates an electric field.

(Figure 9.2) 
>>>image(energy level diagram.png.0)

#### Absorption

Silicon is what is called an **indirect band gap semiconductor**, which
means that the valence band edge and the conduction band edge are not
aligned, and thus despite its small band gap of only 1.1 eV, silicon
must be a few tens of microns thick in order to absorb all incident
photons with energy in excess of the band gap.[^9.1.2] In the cases where a
photon is successfully absorbed by the silicon in a p-n junction, the
electron in the conduction band and the hole left behind in the valence
band dissociate from each other immediately. Once separated, these
photogenerated electrons and holes actually have negative and positive
charges associated with them. The fact that the opposite charges do not
immediately recombine is due to the relatively high dielectric constant
of silicon, which lowers the electrostatic potential energy of the
individual charges.

#### The photovoltaic effect

Eventually, the charges feel the pull of the built-in electric field of
the depletion zone and are shuttled to opposite ends of the device. The
difference in potential energy per charge---i.e., the voltage of the
device---depends on the difference in energy between the conduction band
of the p-type side and the valence band of the n-type side (since those
are the bands where the charges live). When there is no load connected
to the device (or a load of infinite resistance), this voltage is called
the **open-circuit voltage, *V*$_{oc}$** When the two sides of the
device are connected with a thick metal wire (effectively zero
resistance), the charges move into the circuit to recombine with each
other. The resulting maximum possible current is called the
**short-circuit current, *I*$_{sc}$**. When a load is placed in between
the two terminals, the maximum power achievable is ideally equal to
*V*$_{oc}$ $\times$ *I*$_{sc}$ but never is. Instead, various parasitic
processes in the device reduce the maximum power to something like
60-95% of the ideal value. The ratio of this value to the ideal value is
called the **fill factor**. The ratio of the maximum power to the input
solar power is the **power conversion efficiency**. The diagram shown in
Figure (9.3) depicts how these values relate to one another.

### 9.1.2. Excitonic solar cells

There is another type of solar cell based on organic semiconductors and
semiconductor nanocrystals (i.e., quantum dots). This type of solar
cell---termed an **excitonic solar cell**---differs from conventional
silicon solar cells in several ways, enumerated as follows.

1.  The dielectric constant of the medium is lower than silicon.

2.  The low dielectric constant means that that photogenerated charges
    are not separated immediately. Instead, an electrostatically bound
    and neutral electron-hole pair---**an exciton**---is generated.

3.  This exciton must reach an interface between a material which is an
    electron donor and one which is an electron acceptor.

4.  The donor serves the same function as the p-type silicon in a
    conventional cell, but the donor is not doped and thus has no mobile
    charge carriers.

5.  Since there is no doping, putting a donor and an acceptor in
    intimate contact does not produce a depletion zone.

6.  Most organic semiconductors and quantum dots are **direct band gap
    semiconductors**, which means that they can be up to 1000$\times$
    thinner than silicon cells.

7.  Excitonic materials can often be deposited from solution over large
    areas and at low cost.

8.  Unfortunately, excitonic solar cells have lower efficiencies and
    device lifetimes compared to conventional silicon cells.

#### Generation of photovoltage in excitonic cells

Given all of the ways in which these excitonic---"alternative"---types
of semiconductors differ from conventional silicon, it is surprising
that they exhibit a photovoltaic effect at all. With no depletion layer,
one may question how the charges reach the opposite sides of the device.
In the case of excitonic cells, it is essential that the metallic
electrodes used to extract the charges have different values of **work
function**. The work function of the anode should be close to the
valence band edge of the donor (where the holes come out, very roughly
around 5 eV), and the work function of the cathode must be close to the
conduction band edge of the acceptor (where the electrons come out, very
roughly around 3 eV). When the electrodes are connected, there is a
shuttling of electrons from the cathode to the anode, and thus the
cathode takes on a small positive charge and the anode takes on a small
negative charge. Thus, an electric field is created in the device. Once
the exciton splits into free charge carriers---i.e., where the electron
goes to the acceptor and the hole goes into the donor---the electric
field in the device causes the electrons to drift toward the cathode and
the holes to drift toward the anode. This process is the basis of the
photovoltaic effect in excitonic solar cells.

One major complication of the excitonic solar cell is that the distance
an exciton can travel---**exciton diffusion length**---is typically 5-10
times shorter than the thickness of the film needed to absorb most of
the light, which for our purposes can be taken as the **absorption
length**. Thus, typical exciton diffusion lengths are on the order of 10
nm, while typical absorption lengths can be on the order of 100 nm. A
consequence of this disparity is that devices with a flat, planar
interface between the donor and the acceptor are inherently inefficient.
The reason is that for devices with thicknesses of 100 nm, most of the
excitons generated will not reach the interface, and will just collapse:
the energy will either be radiated as a fluorescent photon or it will be
lost as heat. For devices of 10 nm or so in thickness, most of the
excitons will find the interface and separate, but most of the light
will pass through the device, unabsorbed.

The most common way around this challenge is to cast both the donor and
the acceptor material from the same solution. Under favorable
conditions, the two materials separate into a donor phase and an
acceptor phase whose dimensions are close to the exciton diffusion
length, but whose overall thickness is close to the absorption length.
The resulting blended architecture is called the **bulk
heterojunction**, see Figure (9.4). This architecture simplifies
processing but has some disadvantages, as enumerated below.

(Figure 9.4)

1.  The donor and the acceptor phases make contact with both electrodes

2.  Some donor and acceptor phases get "stranded" like an island in a
    sea of the other material

3.  The chemical potential gradient established for a planar device
    which ordinarily pushes charges in the correct direction now faces
    in random directions

Methods to achieve the best of both worlds of the planar and bulk
heterojunction involve the fabrication of an **ordered bulk
heterojunction** in which top-down nanolithography or bottom-up self
assembly processes are used to create precisely interpenetrating
networks with bicontinuity of the two phases. Notwithstanding, these
efforts have so far not been successful, and the bulk heterojunction
type excitonic solar cell (typically polymer based) is the most
efficient type of excitonic solar cell. Moreover, it is becoming
increasingly apparent that some level of molecular mixing at the
interfaces (shown as the purple "halos" around the red and blue phases

geometry in which the layers are perfectly separated.

### 9.1.3. Perovskite solar cells

A final type of solar cell which has some characteristics of the
excitonic solar cell, especially its ultrathin stature, is the
**perovskite solar cell**. A perovksite cell is so named because the
crystal structure of the semiconductor absorber is the same as the
mineral with the name of perovskite, CaTiO$_3$. The general formula is
ABX$_3$, where A is usually a polar organic molecule (methylammonium,
CH$_3$NH$_3$), B is a metal, and X is a halide. The composition of
perovskite materials that is among the most promising---or at least
where most of the research is headed---is methylammonium lead iodide,
CH$_3$NH$_3$PbI$_3$, see Figure (9.5).

(Figure 9.5) 
>>>image(perovskite.png.0)

The way in which a perovskite device works has elements of both a
conventional (i.e., silicon) and excitonic (i.e., organic) solar cell.
First off, the perovskite material is a direct bandgap semiconductor,
meaning that the device can be very thin.[^9.1.3] The perovskite structure
also has a high dielectric constant, and shields charges effectively.
Thus, as soon as a photon is absorbed, free charges are immediately
generated. These charges drift around the active layer. What is required
is charge-selective contacts that shuttle either electrons, **the
electron transport layer (ETL)**, or holes, **the hole transport layer
(HTL)**, out to the electrodes. This selective separation of charges is
the basis of the photovoltaic effect in perovskite solar cells. Often,
the ETL, HTL, or both, are organic, and sometimes are $\pi$-conjugated
polymers. Thus, innovations in the chemistry and physics of organic
semiconductors could be useful in the development of perovskite devices.

### 9.1.4. Tandem solar cells

There are many ways in which combining the attributes of solar cells are
advantageous. For example, connecting cells in parallel can generate
larger currents (equivalent to increasing the size of a single cell).
Conversely, connecting cells in series can generate larger voltages.
Connection in series enables one to create **tandem devices**, in which
different cells with different absorption characteristics are
constructed on top of one another, like a stack of pancakes (Figure
(9.6)). This approach allows one to tailor the absorption properties of
a collection of cells to cover as much of the solar spectrum as
possible. For example, a large-bandgap semiconductor (absorbs
higher-energy, bluer light) might sit atop a low-bandgap semiconductor
(absorbs lower-energy, redder light). To reiterate, when one connects
cells in parallel, one adds up the currents of the individual cells, and
when one connects cells in series, one adds up the voltages.

Interactions between light and matter determine much about the way that
sighted individuals observe the world. Indeed, absorption and scattering
largely determine which photons reach our eyes in the natural
environment. In technology, the engineering of light-matter interactions
is critical in two areas of application: solar photovoltaic cells and
devices for lighting and display. This chapter reviews some of the basic
principles of these devices. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/zZg5MXKCwCI)

The photophysical processes we have discussed so far are central to the
operation of solar cells and light-emitting devices. The first step in
the operation of a solar cell occurs when a semiconductor material in
the **photoactive layer** absorbs a photon. This material can absorb
photons with energy equal to or in excess of its band gap, where the
probability of photon absorption depends on the material's absorptivity
and density of states. The absorption of a photon will cause the
excitation of an electron, followed by rapid thermalization of the
electron to the band edge. This process produces an electron, $e^-$, in
the conduction band and leaves a hole, h$^+$, in the valence band. From
there, the details differ depending on the type of solar cell being
discussed.

### 9.1.1. Silicon solar cells

Conventional solar cells based on polycrystalline or monocrystalline
silicon are what---at the time of this writing---are probably on the
roof of a nearby building, or the building you are in. This technology
currently exhibits the best compromise between efficiency, lifetime,
stability, and cost.

#### p-n Junctions

The basic architecture of a silicon solar cell is a **p-n junction**
(see Figure (9.1)), in which a slab of p-type silicon makes intimate
contact with a slab of n-type silicon. Normal silicon is tetravalent,
meaning that it makes four bonds to nearby atoms. The structure of
crystalline silicon has a tetrahedral arrangement, which is the same
structure as diamond.[^9.1.1] Due to this state in which all covalent bonds
exactly satisfy the preferred bonding arrangement for silicon, the
electrons are not very mobile. Thus, pure silicon is not very conductive
at all, exhibiting borderline insulating behavior at room temperature.

(Figure 9.1) 
>>>image(p-n junction.png.0)

#### Doping

When atoms are added to the structure of pure silicon in a process
called **doping**, the conductivity is altered. For example, "p-type"
silicon is so-called because it is doped with an element with a valency
of less than four. The most common p-type dopant is boron, which has
three valence electrons. When boron is added to silicon (in minute
quantities \<\<1%), there is a **hole** in the crystal structure due to
a "missing" electron since boron can only form a full covalent bond with
up to three of its neighbors. This hole can backfill with a nearby
electron, which thus creates a hole in the bond between two silicon
atoms. The backfilling of these holes by electrons is the mechanism by
which p-type silicon conducts electricity. For n-type silicon, the most
common elements used as dopants are phosphorus or arsenic, which each
have five valence electrons. In this case, electrical conduction is
achieved by the movement of these "extra" electrons.

It is important to remember that neither p-type nor n-type silicon is
formally charged. Saying that the silicon is p-type does not mean it
carries a positive charge. Remember that while there are "missing"
electrons because there are boron atoms in the crystal lattice, boron
also has one fewer proton than silicon. This point is easy to forget.

#### Formation of the depletion zone

When p-type and n-type silicon are pressed together to form a p-n
junction, something weird happens. Some of the extra electrons from the
n-type side migrate over to the p-type side in order to satisfy the
unfilled valencies. The result of this migration is that *the p-type
side becomes negatively charged and the n-type side becomes positively
charged!* The charged zones near the interface do not penetrate all the
way into either side of the junction. The width---**the depletion
zone**---depends on doping level of the silicon and ultimately on the
increase in electrostatic potential energy due to confining charges
nearby one another. Nevertheless, the positive and negative charges on
either side of the depletion zone form an electric field. This built-in
field is capable of sorting negative and positive charges to opposite
sides of the junction. The following figure, (9.2), depicts how a p-n
junction creates an electric field.

(Figure 9.2) 
>>>image(energy level diagram.png.0)

#### Absorption

Silicon is what is called an **indirect band gap semiconductor**, which
means that the valence band edge and the conduction band edge are not
aligned, and thus despite its small band gap of only 1.1 eV, silicon
must be a few tens of microns thick in order to absorb all incident
photons with energy in excess of the band gap.[^9.1.2] In the cases where a
photon is successfully absorbed by the silicon in a p-n junction, the
electron in the conduction band and the hole left behind in the valence
band dissociate from each other immediately. Once separated, these
photogenerated electrons and holes actually have negative and positive
charges associated with them. The fact that the opposite charges do not
immediately recombine is due to the relatively high dielectric constant
of silicon, which lowers the electrostatic potential energy of the
individual charges.

#### The photovoltaic effect

Eventually, the charges feel the pull of the built-in electric field of
the depletion zone and are shuttled to opposite ends of the device. The
difference in potential energy per charge---i.e., the voltage of the
device---depends on the difference in energy between the conduction band
of the p-type side and the valence band of the n-type side (since those
are the bands where the charges live). When there is no load connected
to the device (or a load of infinite resistance), this voltage is called
the **open-circuit voltage, *V*$_{oc}$** When the two sides of the
device are connected with a thick metal wire (effectively zero
resistance), the charges move into the circuit to recombine with each
other. The resulting maximum possible current is called the
**short-circuit current, *I*$_{sc}$**. When a load is placed in between
the two terminals, the maximum power achievable is ideally equal to
*V*$_{oc}$ $\times$ *I*$_{sc}$ but never is. Instead, various parasitic
processes in the device reduce the maximum power to something like
60-95% of the ideal value. The ratio of this value to the ideal value is
called the **fill factor**. The ratio of the maximum power to the input
solar power is the **power conversion efficiency**. The diagram shown in
Figure (9.3) depicts how these values relate to one another.

### 9.1.2. Excitonic solar cells

There is another type of solar cell based on organic semiconductors and
semiconductor nanocrystals (i.e., quantum dots). This type of solar
cell---termed an **excitonic solar cell**---differs from conventional
silicon solar cells in several ways, enumerated as follows.

1.  The dielectric constant of the medium is lower than silicon.

2.  The low dielectric constant means that that photogenerated charges
    are not separated immediately. Instead, an electrostatically bound
    and neutral electron-hole pair---**an exciton**---is generated.

3.  This exciton must reach an interface between a material which is an
    electron donor and one which is an electron acceptor.

4.  The donor serves the same function as the p-type silicon in a
    conventional cell, but the donor is not doped and thus has no mobile
    charge carriers.

5.  Since there is no doping, putting a donor and an acceptor in
    intimate contact does not produce a depletion zone.

6.  Most organic semiconductors and quantum dots are **direct band gap
    semiconductors**, which means that they can be up to 1000$\times$
    thinner than silicon cells.

7.  Excitonic materials can often be deposited from solution over large
    areas and at low cost.

8.  Unfortunately, excitonic solar cells have lower efficiencies and
    device lifetimes compared to conventional silicon cells.

#### Generation of photovoltage in excitonic cells

Given all of the ways in which these excitonic---"alternative"---types
of semiconductors differ from conventional silicon, it is surprising
that they exhibit a photovoltaic effect at all. With no depletion layer,
one may question how the charges reach the opposite sides of the device.
In the case of excitonic cells, it is essential that the metallic
electrodes used to extract the charges have different values of **work
function**. The work function of the anode should be close to the
valence band edge of the donor (where the holes come out, very roughly
around 5 eV), and the work function of the cathode must be close to the
conduction band edge of the acceptor (where the electrons come out, very
roughly around 3 eV). When the electrodes are connected, there is a
shuttling of electrons from the cathode to the anode, and thus the
cathode takes on a small positive charge and the anode takes on a small
negative charge. Thus, an electric field is created in the device. Once
the exciton splits into free charge carriers---i.e., where the electron
goes to the acceptor and the hole goes into the donor---the electric
field in the device causes the electrons to drift toward the cathode and
the holes to drift toward the anode. This process is the basis of the
photovoltaic effect in excitonic solar cells.

One major complication of the excitonic solar cell is that the distance
an exciton can travel---**exciton diffusion length**---is typically 5-10
times shorter than the thickness of the film needed to absorb most of
the light, which for our purposes can be taken as the **absorption
length**. Thus, typical exciton diffusion lengths are on the order of 10
nm, while typical absorption lengths can be on the order of 100 nm. A
consequence of this disparity is that devices with a flat, planar
interface between the donor and the acceptor are inherently inefficient.
The reason is that for devices with thicknesses of 100 nm, most of the
excitons generated will not reach the interface, and will just collapse:
the energy will either be radiated as a fluorescent photon or it will be
lost as heat. For devices of 10 nm or so in thickness, most of the
excitons will find the interface and separate, but most of the light
will pass through the device, unabsorbed.

The most common way around this challenge is to cast both the donor and
the acceptor material from the same solution. Under favorable
conditions, the two materials separate into a donor phase and an
acceptor phase whose dimensions are close to the exciton diffusion
length, but whose overall thickness is close to the absorption length.
The resulting blended architecture is called the **bulk
heterojunction**, see Figure (9.4). This architecture simplifies
processing but has some disadvantages, as enumerated below.

#### Section 2: Light-emitting devices and display technologies
While solar cells convert light to electricity, light-emitting devices
and displays convert electricity to light. Display technologies have
always been intimately connected to methods of generating light for
interior and exterior use. For example, incandescent light bulbs lit
rooms and streets as well as provided the back light for movie
projectors. Nowadays, the technology that underlies most indoor,
outdoor, and automotive lighting is the **light-emitting diode (LED)**.
An LED is essentially a solar cell in reverse. That is, charges are
injected into the semiconductor, and when they recombine, they emit a
photon, in a process known as **electroluminescence**. This process is
ubiquitous in current display technologies, but there are important
differences between them. These differences can be obscured by the often
confusing language with which they are referred. For example, devices
labeled "LED" and "OLED" operate using principles which differ
considerably from each other.

### 9.2.1. Brief history of display technologies

We are approaching the generation of college students who never used a
**cathode ray tube (CRT)** television or computer monitor. A
**monochrome** (single-color) CRT display uses a vacuum tube with an
electron gun in the back of the display. Electrons are emitted by a
process called **thermionic emission** in which a metal filament is
heated up at the cathode and accelerated toward the screen by a high
voltage. An electromagnetic field scans this **cathode ray** across the
screen in a pattern defined by the input. As the ray scans across
**phosphors**[^9.2.1] embedded in the glass screen, an image is created. A
color display[^9.2.2] has three different types of phosphors, which emit
red, green, and blue when impinged upon by a beam of electrons (the
cathode ray).

For most of the history of CRT displays, they were configured as
**analog**. That is, they produced images in response to a continuously
variable signal. With analog technology, errors are propagated easily
and highly susceptible to interference. Those of us who have ever
fiddled with rabbit-ear antennae to improve the quality of the picture
on a TV can attest. The maximum resolution of a CRT display is defined
by the **dot pitch**, or the spacing between triads of RGB
color-emitting phosphors.

In contrast to an analog display, which is subject to the accumulation
of error, a digital display permits much more accurate and error-free
rendering of images. Most modern displays---your TV, laptop, and
smartphone---are digital. The advent of digital displays corresponded to
a progression of flat-screen technologies that has largely supplanted
CRT displays. The first widely adopted flat-panel displays were based on
**plasma** and **liquid crystal** technologies.

### 9.2.2. Digital display technologies

Plasma displays are glass panels with little closed pockets of inert gas
sandwiched by transparent conductive electrodes. A **radio frequency
(RF)** electrical signal ionizes the gas in the pockets to form a
**plasma**. These charged species excite phosphors embedded in the
interior surface of the glass, which emit light. There are three
**subpixels**---red, green, and blue---per pixel in a color display. The
number of pixels is equal to the resolution, for example, 1920 $\times$
1080.[^9.2.3]

#### Liquid crystal displays

A **liquid crystal display (LCD)** is a type of flat-panel technology
that uses a layer of liquid crystals to control how much light is
passing between a white backlight and a large array of RGB color
filters. Figure (9.7) shows the concept. First of all, a liquid crystal
is a type of material, described in Chapter 6, in which the liquid
phase, at certain temperature, has the unusual property of molecular
alignment. These aligned molecules can interact with unpolarized light,
and thus only polarized light may pass through. The concept is exploited
in polarized sunglasses. If you put these glasses under a microscope,
you will find a series of microscopic dark lines arrayed like Venetian
blinds. These lines block out half of the light, and what light passes
through becomes polarized along the axis of the lines. In fact, if you
take your polarized sunglasses and rotate them (or tip your head 90
$^{\circ}$ ) while looking at an LCD, it will go dark. The near-total
loss of light intensity reaching your eyes occurs because the polarized
light that emerges from the display is blocked by the polarizer in your
sunglasses, if your sunglasses are oriented at 90 $^{\circ}$ . Two
sunglasses lenses placed at 90 $^{\circ}$ to each other will have the
same effect. However, if you put multiple polarizers in a stack, and
rotate each one from 0 to 90 $^{\circ}$ , you will actually let the
light through. With this trick, you are effectively rotating the light
gradually, through each polarizer, like a spiral. Thus, each polarizer
rotates the light a little bit, so that it reaches the final polarizer
which is oriented such as to let the light through. This is the
principle by which an LCD works.

(Figure 9.7) 
>>>image(LCD.png.0)

The steps are as follows. First, light is generated by a **backlight**,
typically by an array of conventional silicon LEDs.[^9.2.4] The light then
passes through an electrode connected to a polarizer. The kind of
polarizer used in LCDs contains parallel microscopic grooves. The next
layer is the liquid crystal layer. Rigid, rod-like molecules like those
that form liquid crystals sit in these grooves with their axes oriented
in the same direction as the grooves. Following the liquid crystal layer
is another polarizer oriented 90 $^{\circ}$ to the first. Where the
liquid crystal layer comes into contact with this second polarizer, it
must perform a quarter twist in the space between the two polarizers in
a process called **self-assembly**. The next layer is another electrode,
followed by a color filter. That is, a little piece of dyed plastic or
glass, which lets through red, green, or blue light through. When light
of different intensities are passed through adjacent red, green, and
blue subpixels, nearly any color can be generated---that is, when
observed by somebody some distance away.[^9.2.5]

The intensity of the light coming through each subpixel is controlled by
the electrical potential difference (i.e., the voltage) between the
electrodes on either side of the liquid crystal layer. When no voltage
is applied, the light from the backlight is rotated 90 $^{\circ}$ from
the rear polarizer to the front polarizer. So, while half the light is
blocked by the first polarizer---nothing you can do about that---the
rest of the light passes through to the color filter. However, when
voltage is applied, you can get the quarter turn of the liquid crystal
to straighten out and become parallel to either the front or back
polarizer. When the voltage is at maximum, all of the light is
blocked.[^9.2.6] The voltage at each subpixel is controlled by arrays of
transparent **thin-film transistors** at every location in an
**active-matrix** display. Advantages of LCD technology are that they
use relatively low energy (compared to plasma displays) and are
relatively inexpensive to manufacture. The significant downside of LCDs
is that since the backlight is always on, and there is always some
leakage through the LC layer, it is difficult to achieve very high
levels of contrast between light and dark pixels.

#### Organic light-emitting displays (OLEDs)

The issue of relatively low contrast in LCDs can be addressed by using a
separate backlight for each subpixel. That way, pixels can truly be off,
permitting an effective "infinite" contrast ratio between adjacent
pixels in the display. The only technology for backlighting currently
capable of the required resolution is the **organic light-emitting
device (OLED)**. The resolution is achieved by evaporation of organic
semiconductor molecules through a stencil mask with very small holes.
These molecules when electrically stimulated emit white light. The white
light then travels through the RGB color filters at an intensity
determined by the voltage applied to the OLED backlights. Note that no
liquid crystal layer is required in this case, though most commercial
OLED displays still use the color filters. Figure (9.8) illustrates the
operation of a pixel in such a display. You might ask why the organic
semiconductors are not designed simply to emit red, green, and blue,
without the need of the semiconductors. It turns out that while red and
green are amenable to this approach, blue is not. The reason is that
organic semiconductors that emit blue degrade faster than those emitting
red and green. This unequal rate of degradation produces an uneven color
gamut over time.

(Figure 9.8)

#### Displays using quantum dots.

Quantum dots are fluorescent nanoparticles that have many of the same
properties as organic semiconductors. However, when you see a "QLED"
display at the store, the display does not work by the same principle as
an OLED. Instead, a QLED display is basically the same thing as an LCD,
except that a diffuser panel covered in quantum dots is inserted in
front of the LED backlight. The quantum dot layer absorbs the high
energy photons of the white light---which apparently are not pleasing to
the eye---and re-emits them as fluorescent photons with lower energy. A
newer generation of displays enabled by quantum dots is under active
investigation. This technology works analogously to OLEDs, except that
quantum dots are less susceptible to degradation, meaning that it may be
possible to have direct RGB emission and thus eliminate the need for the
color filters all together.

Solar cells and lighting (display) technologies represent real, tangible
applications of photophysical processes in nanoscale materials. They are
also of interest to researchers concerned with generation and efficient
use of energy. For solar cells, researchers are constantly trying to
optimize devices to produce more energy at lower costs by reducing
thermalization losses, developing tandem devices, and researching
nanoscale processes for light management (i.e., using plasmonic antenna
structures or topographic light-trapping features). While displays do
not account for a huge amount of global energy expenditure, displays are
intimately linked to lighting technologies. Domestic, commercial, and
outdoor lighting in fact do consume a significant amount of energy, and
I hope that this chapter allowed you to consider some of the ways in
which nanoengineering can be used to improve them.

1.  The dielectric constant of the medium is lower than silicon.

2.  The low dielectric constant means that that photogenerated charges
    are not separated immediately. Instead, an electrostatically bound
    and neutral electron-hole pair---**an exciton**---is generated.

3.  This exciton must reach an interface between a material which is an
    electron donor and one which is an electron acceptor.

4.  The donor serves the same function as the p-type silicon in a

electrodes used to extract the charges have different values of **work

excitons will find the interface and separate, but most of the light

acceptor phase whose dimensions are close to the exciton diffusion

of less than four. The most common p-type dopant is boron, which has
three valence electrons. When boron is added to silicon (in minute
quantities \<\<1%), there is a **hole** in the crystal structure due to
a "missing" electron since boron can only form a full covalent bond with
up to three of its neighbors. This hole can backfill with a nearby
electron, which thus creates a hole in the bond between two silicon
atoms. The backfilling of these holes by electrons is the mechanism by
which p-type silicon conducts electricity. For n-type silicon, the most
common elements used as dopants are phosphorus or arsenic, which each
have five valence electrons. In this case, electrical conduction is
achieved by the movement of these "extra" electrons.

It is important to remember that neither p-type nor n-type silicon is
formally charged. Saying that the silicon is p-type does not mean it
carries a positive charge. Remember that while there are "missing"
electrons because there are boron atoms in the crystal lattice, boron
also has one fewer proton than silicon. This point is easy to forget.

#### Formation of the depletion zone

When p-type and n-type silicon are pressed together to form a p-n
junction, something weird happens. Some of the extra electrons from the
n-type side migrate over to the p-type side in order to satisfy the
unfilled valencies. The result of this migration is that *the p-type
side becomes negatively charged and the n-type side becomes positively
charged!* The charged zones near the interface do not penetrate all the
way into either side of the junction. The width---**the depletion
zone**---depends on doping level of the silicon and ultimately on the
increase in electrostatic potential energy due to confining charges
nearby one another. Nevertheless, the positive and negative charges on
either side of the depletion zone form an electric field. This built-in
field is capable of sorting negative and positive charges to opposite
sides of the junction. The following figure, (9.2), depicts how a p-n
junction creates an electric field.

#### Absorption

Silicon is what is called an **indirect band gap semiconductor**, which
means that the valence band edge and the conduction band edge are not
aligned, and thus despite its small band gap of only 1.1 eV, silicon
must be a few tens of microns thick in order to absorb all incident
photons with energy in excess of the band gap.[^9.1.2] In the cases where a
photon is successfully absorbed by the silicon in a p-n junction, the
electron in the conduction band and the hole left behind in the valence
band dissociate from each other immediately. Once separated, these
photogenerated electrons and holes actually have negative and positive
charges associated with them. The fact that the opposite charges do not
immediately recombine is due to the relatively high dielectric constant
of silicon, which lowers the electrostatic potential energy of the
individual charges.

#### The photovoltaic effect

Eventually, the charges feel the pull of the built-in electric field of
the depletion zone and are shuttled to opposite ends of the device. The
difference in potential energy per charge---i.e., the voltage of the
device---depends on the difference in energy between the conduction band
of the p-type side and the valence band of the n-type side (since those
are the bands where the charges live). When there is no load connected
to the device (or a load of infinite resistance), this voltage is called
the **open-circuit voltage, *V*$_{oc}$** When the two sides of the
device are connected with a thick metal wire (effectively zero
resistance), the charges move into the circuit to recombine with each
other. The resulting maximum possible current is called the
**short-circuit current, *I*$_{sc}$**. When a load is placed in between
the two terminals, the maximum power achievable is ideally equal to
*V*$_{oc}$ $\times$ *I*$_{sc}$ but never is. Instead, various parasitic
processes in the device reduce the maximum power to something like
60-95% of the ideal value. The ratio of this value to the ideal value is
called the **fill factor**. The ratio of the maximum power to the input
solar power is the **power conversion efficiency**. The diagram shown in
Figure (9.3) depicts how these values relate to one another.
